title.narrative: Humanitarian Innovation Fund 2019-2023

description.narrative: The HIF is a globally-recognised programme leading on the development and testing of innovation in the humanitarian system.
To improve outcomes for people affected by humanitarian crises by identifying, nurturing and sharing more effective and scalable solutions.

participating-org.narrative: Agha Khan Agency for Habitat India
Center for Disaster Preparedness Foundation Inc
Dahdaleh Institute for Global Health Research, York University
International Federation of the Red Cross and Red Crescent (IFRC)
J-PAL Europe, Paris School of Economics
London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine
Research and Grant Institute of Ghana
Terre des hommes- Aide à l'enfance dans le monde- Fondation
University of Applied Sciences and Arts Northwestern Switzerland (FHNW)

sector.narrative: Including support for grassroots innovation, scaling of innovations, and other innovation-related projects

2019 Q4 EA002 WASH - Grants S15821 RESEARCH AND GRANT INSTITUTE OF GHANA

description.narrative: WASH - Grants S15821 RESEARCH AND GRANT INSTITUTE OF GHANA

receiver-org.narrative: RESEARCH AND GRANT INSTITUTE OF GHANA

title.narrative: HIF supports the development, evidencing and scaling of promising WASH innovations in humanitarian contexts to strategically address priority problems.
3.1 # innovation challenges launched and projects funded addressing clear needs/gaps in priority areas as determined by evidence-based research

comment.narrative: 5 Challenges and 16 projects (cumulative); (4 from MHM 2019, 3 from Incontinence 2019, 3 from Evidence Challenge 2020, 3 from FSM Challenge 2020, 3 from Adoption Challenge 2021) NB: Baseline not included in the total.
1 Challenge completed: FSM; Adoption Challenge in progress, with 32 full proposals under review by Technical Reviewers. Grantee project funding on hold

title.narrative: Support is provided to local innovators to develop solutions with the potential for sustainability and scale
6.3 # and type of learning outputs generated and shared between the initiatives and with the broader sector

comment.narrative: 7 learning resources produced

1 Produced: Co-developed a community-leadership framework across the partnership for piloting in the next 6 months. In progress: Wrote a blog on community-led approaches; Wrote an article on community-led innovation as a pathway to decolonisation and anti-racism. Linked to the above article, in process of co-organising an associated panel for the Humanitarian Leadership Conference at the end of April 2021. In progress the first research report on indigenous values and practices of innovation, due to be finalised in May 2021.

title.narrative: The most promising humanitarian innovations are funded and intentensively supported to scale
5.3 # convening / consultation events with experts to address the barriers to scale/ further humanitarian innovation at scale (e.g. Donors Group)

comment.narrative: 6 events (cumulative) 4 round table events, 1 Forum session and 1 virtual session NB: Baseline not included in the total.
1 achieved: 1 x round table convened to develop and validate the learning paper Impact Evidence and Beyond: Using Evidence to Drive Adoption of Humanitarian Innovations.

title.narrative: Investment in a new HIF innovation portfolio addressing priority evidence-based gaps on the inclusion of people with disabilities and older people
1.4 % HIF-funded innovation projects led by, or demonstrating meaningful partnership with, organisations for persons with disabilities (DPOs) or older persons associations (OPAs)

comment.narrative: Cumulative
100% - all funded projects have partnerships with OPAs or OPDs.

title.narrative: Support is provided to local innovators to develop solutions with the potential for sustainability and scale
6.4 # of local grantees and other local partners reporting that HIF built their capacity on key elements of good practice in humanitarian innovation. (Disaggregated by type of partner)

comment.narrative: 35 reporting capacity built (cumulative) of which x grantees x local organisations NB: Baseline not included in the total.
13 total: 10 x innovation teams selected and participating in remote workshop training for Round 2 India; 3 x Country 2 (India) grantees receiving regular guidance from HIF and SEEDS team

title.narrative: HIF supports the development, evidencing and scaling of promising WASH innovations in humanitarian contexts to strategically address priority problems.
3.3 # convening / consultation events with WASH experts to further humanitarian innovation (e.g. Technical Working Group)

comment.narrative: 6 meetings/events (cumulative); 4 TWG meetings convened 2 Innovation Showcases convened NB: Baseline not included in the total.
2 convening events: 2 x TWG meetings convened virtually in October 2020 and March 2021. The TWG remains active and engaged, and the attendance is usually at least 80% at meetings.

title.narrative: HIF supports GBV innovations addressing priority problems, and generates learning and demand for innovation across the humanitarian GBV sector
2.2 # convening / consultation events with GBV experts to further humanitarian innovation (e.g. Technical Working Group)

comment.narrative: 14 Events (cumulative)

2 events: Design for Safety and Gender, Royal College of Arts (RCA) (Oct 2020); Design, Humanitarianism and Gender Roundtable, RCA (March 2021) Further TWG meetings have been conducted and/or scheduled beyond this reporting period.

title.narrative: HIF supports GBV innovations addressing priority problems, and generates learning and demand for innovation across the humanitarian GBV sector
2.4 # and type of non-financial support interventions delivered to # GBV grantees

comment.narrative: 6 instances of non-financial support (cumulative); est 6 GBV grantees participate in 3 Workshops

2 interventions: 1 x grantee kick-off workshop held for two GBV grantee teams and all new DOAI grantees (held virtually in March 2021); 1x welcome/kick off calls conducted with all anticipated GBV grantee teams in the IPV cohort (January 2021) Further interventions planned for GBV grantees throughout 2021

title.narrative: Investment in a new HIF innovation portfolio addressing priority evidence-based gaps on the inclusion of people with disabilities and older people
1.5 # and type of non-financial support interventions delivered to DOAI grantees

comment.narrative: 11 support interventions (cumulative)

2 non-financial support interventions delivered: 1 x grantee kick-off workshops with all new DOAI grantees (held virtually in March 2021); 1x kick-off calls with the meaningful participation grantees to begin support to measure effectiveness of their innovations (March 2021) Due to travel restrictions, none of the planned in-person visits to project teams have been made.

title.narrative: Support is provided to local innovators to develop solutions with the potential for sustainability and scale
6.6 # and type of non-financial support interventions delivered to local HIF grantees

comment.narrative: 8 interventions (cumulative) of non-financial support given to grantees and country cohorts NB: Baseline not included in the total.

3 (of 7) virtual workshops delivered. Monthly calls with India cohort 1 grantees and SEEDS India. Ongoing mentoring with both cohorts. Feedback and mentoring on reporting and application for Stage 2 funding (Philippines)

title.narrative: Support is provided to local innovators to develop solutions with the potential for sustainability and scale
6.5 # funding rounds launched and projects funded and supported addressing clear needs/gaps at local level

comment.narrative: 3 funding rounds launched (cumulative) min 12* projects funded cumulative (9 seed funding; 3 follow on) NB: Baseline not included in the total.

4 projects funded: 3 funded projects in India round 1 (November 2020 to May 2021); 1 project selected for Philippines Stage 2 funding (due to commence July 2021). In progress: India cohort 2 funding round due to launch in May 2021 following remote workshop delivery. Delays possible due to changing COVID-19 situation.

title.narrative: Investment in a new HIF innovation portfolio addressing priority evidence-based gaps on the inclusion of people with disabilities and older people
1.2 # convening / consultation events with DOAI experts to further humanitarian innovation (e.g. Technical Working Group)

comment.narrative: 12 events (cumulative) (of which 4 face-to-face)

6 events: 2 x Problem Exploration reflection workshops with sector experts and representatives (Oct 2020); 1 x full Technical working group meeting (Nov 2020); 1 x consultation with members of the International Disability Alliance to feed into 2021 challenge design (Nov 2020); 1 x TWG subgroup to support on design for 2021 challenge (Nov-Dec 2020); 1 x expert reference group consultation to feed into challenge 2021 design (Nov-Dec 2020)

title.narrative: Investment in a new HIF innovation portfolio addressing priority evidence-based gaps on the inclusion of people with disabilities and older people

comment.narrative: 6 Challenges (cumulative) 16 Projects (cumulative)
8 new projects selected from 2020 innovation challenges: 3 projects focusing on meaningful participation, and 5 projects focusing on inclusive preparedness

title.narrative: Resources, technical skills and capabilities on humanitarian Innovation management, including on cutting edge practices, are developed and shared
4.3 # and type of non-financial support events delivered (internally and externally)

comment.narrative: Ethics Toolkit / participatory tools / partnerships tools used by all HIF grantees (as appropriate)

Ethics Toolkit used by 3 cohorts of HIF grantees in joint DOAI and GBV grantee kick-off workshop held in March In progress: Two training sessions are planned for April and June to introduce grantees to the participatory tools/partnerships tools

title.narrative: The most promising humanitarian innovations are funded and intentensively supported to scale
5.2 # and type of non-financial support interventions delivered to J2S grantees

comment.narrative: At least 86 interventions (cumulative) (including workshops, webinars, 1-2-1 coaching/mentoring sessions, project visits etc). Satisfaction, outcomes and willingness to recommend support is tracked and measured regularly, and HIF can demonstrate having acted and adapted to feedback
Further progress against this milestone will take place in the next reporting period

title.narrative: Support is provided to local innovators to develop solutions with the potential for sustainability and scale
6.7 # local non-lead partners (not grant holders) across all HIF-funded challenges consulted and the health of partnerships assessed

comment.narrative: 25 non lead partners (cumulative)
Handbook prepared for potential applicants with templates for Letter of Support, MoU and checklist for lead applicants to consider when submitting an application.

title.narrative: Improved survival, improved lives, reduced losses and/or faster recovery for the most vulnerable people affected by humanitarian crises (including rapid onset, chronic, recurrent or protracted humanitarian crises)
1. # case studies of HIF funded innovations that have directly impacted on humanitarian outcomes.

comment.narrative: 5 impact case studies (cumulative)
Impact Snapshots submitted in August 2020 indicate progress towards achieving impact for several HIF-funded innovations.

title.narrative: Resources, technical skills and capabilities on humanitarian Innovation management, including on cutting edge practices, are developed and shared
4.1 # gap analyses, deep dive reports, scoping studies undertaken to inform problem focus

comment.narrative: 5 scoping / research pieces (cumulative) NB: Baseline not included in the total.
In progress: 1 x scale scoping piece; 1 x building skills scoping report; 2 x research/scoping pieces

title.narrative: Resources, technical skills and capabilities on humanitarian Innovation management, including on cutting edge practices, are developed and shared
4.2 # of new competency areas developed (including tools, methods, approaches) and integrated in the Humanitarian Innovation Guide

comment.narrative: 5-6 new competency areas developed (including ethics, participation, partnerships) and integrated into the Humanitarian Innovation Guide
In progress: Ethics toolkit expected to be finalised in April 2021 (see further update below). Work on participatory and partnerships approaches and tools underway

title.narrative: HIF supports the development, evidencing and scaling of promising WASH innovations in humanitarian contexts to strategically address priority problems.
3.2 # gap analyses, deep dive reports, scoping studies undertaken to inform problem focus

comment.narrative: 4 reports (cumulative); 1 WASH Gap Analysis 2.0 - 2020; 2 additional outputs to scope areas for innovation - TBC and 1 procurement mapping report NB: Baseline not included in the total. 2 additional outputs to scope areas for innovation - output TBC and 1 procurement mapping report) NB: Baseline not included in the total.

In progress: Gap Analysis draft report and analysis complete and due to be launched at the Global WASH Cluster meeting in April 2021. WASH procurement mapping report (in collaboration with Scale area of focus) finalised and due to be launched in June 2021.
